name: places/ChIJp9ku4ahZwokR7166WsDz2K0
formattedAddress: 25 W 32nd St, New York, NY 10001, USA
adrFormatAddress: 25 W 32nd St, New York, NY 10001, USA

originalText.text:
Best Korean skincare in NYC. The girls are really helpful and there's tons of products and make-up despite the shop's small size.
I have to say though, it's a bit pricey, but since all products are imported from Asia and are high quality, it's quite fair.

text.text:

originalText.text: I wish the Face Shop was still in Flushing ( the old one became a Chipotle) but the Manhattan one in Koreatown ( Manhattan) is pretty awesome. If you're a fan, it has all the skincare products you'd expect, plus seasonal goodies. My only complaint? Too many customers in here ( they can't do anything about that, I know) and the ones here, of course they were standing in the skincare section just where I wanted to be, so I had to pretend to look at something else while I waited for them to move. I love the face wash that I bought, though!

originalText.text: Well organized and well maintained skin care shop located in Manhattan’s Korea town.  I was doing window shopping as I find their price is more expensive than in Canada.

text.text: Well organized and well maintained skin care shop located in Manhattan’s Korea town.  I was doing window shopping as I find their price is more expensive than in Canada.

originalText.text:
The worst service I’ve received in years. Has NOTHING to do with traditional Korean politeness or hospitality. It is a shame that they sell BTS products, since the employees are rude and unprofessional.
I wanted to buy a BTS apron that was hanging by itself. So I asked an enployee to show me where I could get one. She asked me if I wantes a NEW one. I mean, do people actuallt come to shop for “oldl ones for that kind of price?
I said “Of course”.
Then she just waved her hand in some vague direction and disappeared. When I failed to find what I was looking for, I said “Could you PLEASE take me where it is?” Walking me to where those aprons were stacked turned out to be a whole new level of “doing a favor” for that young lady…
I do not really understand. Aren’t these employees looking to SELL their stuff? Why is this attitude?
At the register I complained that the lady helping me was not really “helpful”, and in return I heard “Oh, but the CUSTOMERS have to show respect first”. But… how much more are you supposed to “show”? Regular phrases like “hello, excuse me, could you please show me, I would like to, etc.”, are they not working anymore? What does one have to do to be actually “served” in a store?

originalText.text: Staff are not polite. Did not greet my husband and I when we first came in. I asked a worker which skin care product is great for dry skin and she basically looked at me in a rude way then just points at a product.. and walks away.
